prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not wanting a kid that could potential go blind at age 20?
My wife and I are talking about kids. And she has a condition in her family, Retina pigmentosa,  which affects the men of the family. If we have a kid and it is a boy then it has 50% chance of going blind in the late 20s. 

Am I the asshole for thinking that I dont really want to deprive my child of all the joys that life has to offer? 

For example ger father, has never seen his 3 kids. 
He has no job, no social life etc. 

Am I the asshole for not want a future similar to that for my kid? 

This post, in no way intent to patronize, offend or hurt anyone that lives with a disability.  I need to make that very clear. 

Also this is a throwaway account coz wife is lurking around here somewhere! 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

For example, in X-linked recessive, males have one X chromosome; if they inherit the affected one from the mother, they get the condition. The mother is a carrier (XAXa) and the father is normal (XAY), then sons have a 50% chance of XaY (affected) and 50% XAY (normal). So if the mother is a carrier, the sons get either her X or the other X. Since the mother is a carrier (XAXa), the sons would get her X or the other X. But the father's X is not involved here. So if the mother is a carrier, the sons have 50% chance of getting the affected X from her. So in the scenario described, the author and his wife are considering having a son with 50% chance of getting the condition. The author is against having a child, given that possibility. 

Now, the question is whether the author is wrong for this.
